Casehill Woods near Dinas Powys, has resulted in success.National Resources Waleshad proposed constructing a dam m wide and .m high in the meadow at the Woodland Trust site in Dinas Powys.NRW proposed the dam as one option to alleviate potential flood risk.More NewsVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldMillions become unpaid carers due to coronavirus crisisPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownThe campaign by the Save Dinas Powys Woods and Protect Homes from Flooding group was launched in March  after the Woodland Trust said NRW was proposing to build a dam within its site of Cwm George and Casehill Woods.The group said the proposals would involve cutting down  square metres of trees including  square metres of ancient trees and regular flooding upstream during high rainfall would result in further destruction of ancient trees, hedgerows, wildle, and plants.Dormice and other protected species like bats were at risk, the group said.The woods, much-loved by the community, attracts visitors from other areas and is the Woodland Trustrsquos most visited site in Wales with more than , visitors.Hundreds of people took part in marches in  to oppose the dam.NRW released its draft Outline Business Case in February  and a consultation period with the local community took place.Hundreds of people attended a meeting in February to oppose the dam and they wrote to NRW, with their views, during the coronavirus lockdown.Chairman of Save Dinas Powys Woods  Protect Homes From Flooding, Peter Smith said the group welcomed the announcement that NRW will not develop a dam in the Dinas Powys Woods.ldquoLocal people recognise the flood risk in the village, but are overwhelmingly in favour of a natural flood management programmein the Cadoxton River and Eastbrook catchments, plus improved channel maintenance andrequired local hard defences, rather than an environmentally unfriendly dam, Dr Smith said.ldquoOur proposals will slow the flow of the rivers upstream thus reducing the risk of flash flooding, and by removing obstacles improve flow downstream.ldquoWe now look forward to working with NRW and The Woodland Trust to design an effective NFM scheme.ldquoBoth have expertise in this area, and, having made funds available for NFM projects, we know that the Welsh Government is keen for Wales to become an exemplar of good practice. community involvement and support will remain key features of our campaign.He added: ldquoWe are grateful to people far and wide who have supported our campaign, including the Woodland Trust, our local community councils, and county councillors.ldquoWe extend our particular thanks our local MS, Jane Hutt, for her advocacy and support.Community councillor, Chris Franks said NRW must not now ignore any problems.ldquoClearly over the years there has been reduced spending on maintenance of the stream through Dinas Powys and towards Barry, he said.ldquoThe public has said that the NRW must improve monitoring of flows on the Cadoxton River, implement natural flood management measures and improve flow at Cardf Road bridge where the stream passes under the A to reduce flood risk.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquolsquoFollowing our meeting on May  Sir David Henshaw chairman of NRW wrote to me on May  to say that NRW received almost  responses to our consultation on the Outline Business Case with the vast majority being opposed to the upstream storage option on the Cadoxton Brook.NRW chairman, Sir Henshaw said: ldquoWhen we consider the marginal case for this option, it is therefore clear that we will not be pursuing an upstream storage scheme. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net Organisationand recommending people in Wales wear three-layer face coverings in situations where social distancing is not possible.The evidence remains clear that maintaining a two-metre distance and good hand hygiene is the most effective way to protect yourself and others from contracting coronavirus.But updated guidance from the WHO said three layer face coverings could help provide some control of the virus in specic circumstances.This updated advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus.People who are symptomatic must self-isolate for seven days and get a test, as set out in existing guidance.Unless the test shows a negative result, they must not go out during this time, even with a face covering or mask.MORE STORIESWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeContact tracing system for Wales rolled outShielding to continue for , people in WalesHealth minister, Vaughan Gething said: ldquoWashing your hands, avoiding touching your face and maintaining a two-metre distance from others remain the best way of stopping the spread of the virus.ldquoOn Friday , the WHO updated their guidance on face coverings, advising that they should be considered in settings where maintaining social distancing is dficult."However, to be crystal clear, wearing a face covering does not replace the need for social distancing or washing your hands regularly.ldquoFurther scientic evidence is needed on the benefits to the wider public of wearing face coverings, but observational findings so far suggest that homemade or purchased three-layer face-coverings might reduce transmission from one person to anothermade, worn, handled and disposed of properly.ldquoTherefore, on balance, we are recommending to the people of Wales that three-layer face-coverings should be used in situations where social distancing measures can be more dficult to achieve, for example, on public transport."We are not recommending their use outdoors.ldquoThe wearing of face coverings will not be mandatory, but we will encourage people to do this for the benefit of themselves and others.Mr Gething stressed that this advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus, adding: ldquoAnyone who has a high temperature, a new, continuous cough or a loss or change to their sense of smell or taste must self-isolate for a minimum of seven days and get a test as quickly as possible. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA FAIRTRADE coffee farmer who visited Penarth during Fairtrade Fortnight, has spoken of the plight of rural communities during lockdown in Uganda.Three months ago, Jenipher Wetaka Sambazi, a Fairtrade coffee farmer from the Mt Elgon region in Uganda, was sharing her experiences of the benefit of Fairtrade in Penarthrsquos Tabernacle Baptist Church.More NewsVictory in campaign to save Dinas Powys ancient woodland as dam plan is abandonedVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownNow she and her family, like communities around the world, are under lockdown.In March, campaigners, businesses, supporters, and students from around Wales heard Jenipherrsquos story, face to face.Now she is unable to travel or even meet with her neighbours.This means the coffee picked at the end of the last harvest remains on the mountain and Jenipher and her fellow farmers are prohibited from travelling to gather it for processing under the current lockdown rules.There are currently several hundred known cases of covid- in Uganda, but none in the Mount Elgon region and no fatalities in Uganda as yet.Farmers want to keep it this way, but lockdown is causing other concerns such as limiting access to food and healthcare.This is the time of year when there is the least amount of food available, and the closing of markets and freedom to travel for farmers to source food and water means that times are exceptionally hard.Jenipher as vice-chairwoman of a Fairtrade coffee cooperative, is responsible for many who rely on the cooperative for work.The expert hand-sorters who are seasonal workers and rely on this part of the coffee chain to feed their family at this time, have no coffee to sort.While they may have some spare eggs, vegetables or matoke to trade, the threat of soldiers prohibiting them from doing so is too much for them.Farmer co-operatives, an essential element of Fairtrade, enable and encourage communities to work together.Fairtrade also requires an extra amount of money, the Fairtrade premium, to be paid to producers.Fairtrade farmers like Jenipher are struggling, but they have the benefits of a strong local community as well as the backup of the Fairtrade premium.Fairtrade International have announced a .m euro Fairtrade Producer Relief fund targeting the immediate needs and Resilience Fund to help producers rebuild their businesses after Covid-.Jenipher Wettaka Sambazi said: ldquoLe is hard.ldquoThe markets are shut so there is nowhere to sell or earn money, or to buy food and basic essentials.ldquoLocal health centres have been shut to reduce the chance of spreading the virus, but since all transport is banned, those who need operations, treatment or antenatal care need to walk  km to the nearest hospital.ldquoTwo women and their unborn babies have died on the way."Roger Casey, who attends Tabernacle Baptist Church said: ldquoIt was wonderful to meet Jenipher and hear her story.ldquoWe get through a lot of coffee in our office and meeting a real coffee farmer from Uganda makes you think about the real people and real lives behind that Fairtrade logo.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquoMeeting Jenipher during her visit to Wales earlier this year was inspiring.ldquoThe increasing dficulties facing rural farming communities because of the pandemic has shown how important Fairtrade cooperatives continue to be and I am glad that leaders like Jenipher continue to promote the benefits of Fairtrade and to support communities.National co-ordinator of Fair Trade Wales, Aileen Burmeister added: ldquoFair Trade producers are being impacted by covid- restrictions.ldquoGlobal stock markets are falling, meaning that farmers and workers are receiving far less for their produce."It is in these times that we can really see how important the Fairtrade minimum price is. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey stationrsquos Facebook followers are invited to a live online QA session.It is hoped that people will be able to share their memories of the leboat and the contribution that the station has made to first started in , in  the station was closed.However, following a highly successful public campaign an RNLI station was re-established in .The new leboat was housed in a local private garages, but soon a better lsquostationrsquo was developed in the deckchair storebefore moving to its current home, a purpose built station opened in .Gareth Wigmore, one of the first crew members in  and now station president said the leboat was pushed by the crew along the seafront, which at the time wasnrsquot even one way.ldquoWe were as keen as mustard, pleased to be doing our bit for the community, but we had rudimentary equipment back then, he said.ldquoSome of our protective equipment was made by the local community.Crew member Karl Lawrence, with  yearsrsquo experience with the RNLI, said: ldquoThe best part of le-boating is working well as a team.ldquoWe maintain this team spirit by regularly exercising and training both ashore and afloat.ldquoSince opening our new station at the south end of the Esplanade we have installed a training room which is ideal for providing training in a warm, well-lit and stable room, prior to practicing on often rough seas in the leboats.ldquoMy favourite rsquoshoutsrsquo are oddly those which occur in the early hours of the morning on a spring day.ldquoBy the time the job has been completed and the boats are washed down and prepared again for service, we gather on our balcony drinking tea or coffee, watching the sun rise and exchanging with each other our plans for the day ahead, before most other people have woken up.Celebrating the success of the station, current leboat operations manager, Jason Dunlop said ldquoI am incredibly proud to celebrate the stationrsquos -year anniversary.ldquoIt is testament to the community of Penarth who have supported the leboats by providing volunteers, funds, and ongoing support.ldquoThis community effort over the past  years has saved  lives, we have rescued or aided  people and our leboats have launched on service  times.ldquoHundreds of volunteers have supported the RNLI and the station in this time.ldquoI would like to express my thanks to them all and their families.He added: ldquoIt makes no dferencethe role people have played is to crew the boats, to assist launch on shore, provide community safety advice, run our shops or fundraise, everyone plays a vital role in saving lives.ldquoThe RNLI is funded by donations and receives no government funding, soyou are a fundraiser, a member of our shop team, a local business who supports us or a member of the community who has donated or raised funds you have help us to save lives.ldquoWe are all one leboat crew and we are part of the community of Penarth.ldquoThe RNLI is built of the vision that ldquowith courage, nothing is impossible.ldquoI believe that the community of Penarth is a living example of this vision.ldquoAs we say in the RNLI, ldquofair winds and following seas.Leboat spokesman, Andy Berry has asked members the community to send stories and short video messages to awb.safety@gmail where they can be shared online.He said: ldquoMaybe yoursquove been directly involved in a rescue, or perhaps wersquove helped your friends and family  Or maybe you just have a nice story too share about our work or want to wish us well.ldquoWe would love to hear from you.The RNLI, like many charities is facing a funding crisis through the covid- crisis.Penarth RNLI has set up a JustGiving page to help raise monies to mark the th anniversary, with a target of pound.The Penarth Nationwide branch has Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWelsh Government publishes Unlocking Our Society and Economy: Wales coronavirus roadmapPupils willto schools on Monday, June  and the requirement to stay local will be lted,conditions allow on Monday, July .Mr Drakeford is also alerting the visitor and tourism industry to start preparations to reopenthe spread of the virus continues to decline.He said: ldquoThe threat of coronavirus hasnrsquot gone away but thanks to the efforts we have all made over the last few months, the number of people contracting coronavirus each day in Wales is falling, so too is the risk of meeting somebody with virus.ldquoGiven the progress we have made, we are able to take some additional cautious steps to further unlock our society and economy.ldquoThis includes more retailers being able re-open their businesses, as long as they take measures to minimise the risk to their staff and to the customers who visit their stores.ldquoOur focus continues to be on the health risks of the outbreak, but we can now begin to cautiously focus much more squarely on the wider economic and societal impact the virus is having.ldquoWe have provided a huge amount of support to businesses and jobs as they hibernated during the pandemic ndash now we start to take these careful steps to restart our economy.On Monday, a series of changes will be made to the coronavirus regulations ndash the main change will be to enable non-essential retail businesses to open.They follow the fourth statutory review of the coronavirus regulations by Welsh ministers, using the latest scientic and medical evidence from the UK Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , the Welsh Governmentrsquos Technical Advisory Celland the advice from the Chief Medical Officer for Wales.Mondayrsquos changes include enabling private prayer in places of worship where social distancing is maintained and gatherings do not take place restarting the housing market by enabling house viewings to take place in vacant properties and house moves where a sale has been agreed but not yet completed and lting the restrictions on outdoor sports courts, but social distancing must be maintained.No contact or team sports will be allowed.The changes enabling non-professional elite athletes, including Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, to resume training.On June , pupils willto schools to check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September under plans announced by education minister, Kirsty Williams.The requirement to stay local and not generally travelling more than five miles from home remains in place.However, new guidance will make it clear people are able to travel outside their local area on compassionate grounds.This includes seeing people at a care home or a youth offender institution ndash when these visits are allowed.People who are eligible to vote in overseas elections, where voting must be done in person, will also be able to travel.Ministers have decided to lt the requirement to stay local on Monday, July  provided the conditions allow.With the requirement lted, people will be able to travel to tourist attractions across Wales.The first minister is also sending a signal to some businesses and the visitor and tourism industry to use this period to begin to make preparations for reopening.At the next review on Thursday, July , the Welsh Government will consider a range of specic options for opening.These include self-contained holiday accommodation and personal care services, such as hairdressing and beauty, by appointment.Discussions will also be held with the hospitality sector about the potential phased reopening of pubs, cafes, and restaurants while maintaining strict social distancing.Mr Drakeford added: ldquoI know the wider tourism industry is keen to reopen and to salvage some of this summerrsquos season.ldquoI am therefore signalling owners of self-contained accommodation should use the next three weeks to prepare to re-open, working with their local communities.ldquoBut I want people to know coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe have some headroom to make this package of changes to the regulations, which will be introduced in a phased and cautious way in Wales.ldquoMany aspects of daily le in Wales will be moving into the amber zone in our traffic light system.ldquo But we all need to continue to take steps to protect ourselves from the virus ndash that means working from home wherever possible avoiding unnecessary travel only meeting with one other household outdoors maintaining social distancing and washing your hands often.ldquoIt may also mean wearing a face covering in some situations.ldquoIt is thanks to the efforts of everyone in Wales that we have slowed the spread of coronavirus, but we canrsquot stop now.ldquoWe need to do all we can to protect ourselves and our loved ones from the virus and to keep Wales safe. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey These include:Communication of health information, and how effective it isCultural issues relating to the suitability of health and social services for BAME communitiesIncome and employment insecurity, which is experienced disproportionately by BAME communitiesPoor quality of ethnicity data, which is preventing accurate analysisHousing overcrowding and environmentThe financial burden created by migration statusThe role of structural and systemic racism and disadvantage.The report is by the BAME Covid- expert advisory group, set up by First Minister Mark Drakeford to look at the reasons why people from BAME communities were more likely to be adversely affected by coronavirus.:One of its two sub-groups was tasked with examining the socio-economic factors, chaired by Professor Emmanuel Ogbonna, professor of management and organization at Cardf Business School, Cardf University."Therersquos an overall theme running through our research for this report. It centres on long-standing racism and disadvantage, and the lack of BAME representation within decision-making processes," said Professor Ogbonna, who is also a trustee and vice-chair of Race Council Wales.ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic is, in some respects, revealing the consequences of a lack of action on race equality.ldquoMany of the issues wersquove highlighted have been identied and discussed previously, but they havenrsquot been addressed in any systematic and sustained way.Analysis of Covid- related deaths across England and Wales by ethnicity showed that people from a black ethnic background are at a greater risk of death involving COVID- than all other ethnic groups.The Office for National Statistics study showe that the risk for black males has been more than three times higher than white males, and nearly two-and-a-half times higher for black females than white.Adjusting for socio-economic factors and geographical location partly explains the increased risk, but there remains twice the risk for black males and around one-and-a-half times for black females. Signicant dferences also remain for Bangladeshi, Pakistani and Indian men. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff airport introduces coronavirus health safety measures
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMeasures include enhanced cleaning of the whole airport throughout the day and night, plus a deep sanitisation before the terminal re-opens more hand sanitiser stations social distancing for staff and customers, keeping a two-metre distance wherever possible new protective screens in areas such as check in, boarding gates and immigration desks and increased signage and floor markings to help everyone understand the changes to the airport and remind everyone about the safety measures.There will be displays of all the relevant UK and Welsh Government advice and information and a team of lsquoAirport Stewardsrsquo to help customers with the changes throughout the terminal and to be on hand to answer any questions.All airport teams will wear appropriate PPE as required, including face coverings in all areas and passengers are asked to wear three-layer, non-medical face coverings when travelling through the airport before they fly and when they land at Cardf.The airport is encouraging contactless payments throughout the airport where possible asks that only customers and Cardf Airport team to enter the terminal buildings and it is training airport teams about covid- and the safety measures that have been put in place.MORE STORIESCardf Airport announces support for community projectsCardf Airport celebrates decade of charity fundraisingPolice officers welcome NHS supplies to Cardf AirportCustomers are advised to check the lsquoTravel Safersquo guidance on the Cardf Airport website before travelling and are reminded to check their airlinersquos travel regulations before they fly.Customers are asked not to travel to the airportdisplaying any covid- symptoms, to keep a safe distance from others, to frequently wash and sanitise hands, and to wear a three-layer, non-medical face covering at all times in the terminal.Cardf Airport CEO, Deb Bowen Rees said: ldquoThe Airport team have been working hard behind the scenes to ensure that the terminal is ready to welcome passengers in July, when our airlines begin to resume services to and from Cardf."We have introduced a number of measures in line with both Welsh Government and UK Government guidance to protect one another, ensuring that everyone feels safe and confident whilst travelling through and working at Cardf Airport.ldquoWe would also like to remind everyone to be patient, kind and considerate to each other as we all adjust to this new airport experience."The safety and security of our team and passengers remains our number one priority, and we look forward to welcoming customers to the airport in the coming weeks.ldquoThe Cardf Airport airfield has remained open throughout the pandemic to support critical cargo and medical flights, and to ensure that we are in a strong position to re-open for passenger travel."Whilst safety guidance is an important step for the re-commencing of airport operations, we believe that this is only part of the industryrsquos long journey of recovery - the UK Government must review the  day quarantine as a matter of urgency, moving towards a lsquotravel corridorrsquo approach that allows risk-based travel."We also ask the FCO advice is considered to give the industry more clarity on when flying can resume for non-essential travel.The situation regarding the re-start of flying for passenger travel remains fluid and the airport team are in regular dialogue with airlines as to when services will start operating again.Limited services are expected to start flying in July, increasing throughout August, however this could change based on UK Government advice and international travel guidance. article_url allowing members to borrow books, audiobooks and DVDs.Though they remain closed for browsing or use of ICT facilities, libraries in Barry, Penarth, and Cowbridge will be open for this particular service from am to pm and pm to pm Monday to Friday, with Llantwit Major operating in the same way from pm to pm.A maximum of five titles can be requested remotely using the online catalogue and a collection slot can be booked once an email confirming the books are ready has been received.While this system is in operation there will be no loan charges for DVDs or audiobooks.MORE STORIESBarry library closes in wake of coronavirus concernsKevin Moores A Year in Barry exhibition triggers memoriesFuture of Barry Art Central Gallery and other Vale arts services, up for debateVale council cabinet member for education and regeneration, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoWe know what a vital role our libraries play in the lives of some of our residents, especially those who are housebound or cut off from family and friends during this dficult period.ldquoReading in particular is a productive and stimulating way to fill time so Irsquom delighted that we are now able to offer this click and collect service, which allows an inidual to borrow up to five books at any one time.ldquoAudiobooks and DVDs are also available to loan via this contactless system, with users able to view the library catalogue online.ldquoWe hope residents will find this new service helpful while the library buildings and other facilities remain closed.Library users who cannot access the online catalogue to reserve their own books may place a request by phone or email.When the items are ready for collection, they will receive a phone call or an email to book a collection slot.When contacting the library by phone or email to request items, library members should provide their library card number, telephone number and or an email address.They may also submit book requests and preferences, such as a list of favourite authors, genres or specic titles.Library staff will then compile a selection of books for customers to collect at the selected time.Staff will do their best to meet requirements, but the coronavirus crisis has impacted the production and supply of new books and many of the most popular titles may still be on loan.For these reasons the library service is urging people totheir books as soon as possible.When collecting items, a number of measures have been put in place for the safety of customers and staff.Only one member of a household shouldand collect items items can only be title: four doctors reflect th day lockdown
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityFrontline workers have been seen as coronavirus superheroes by members of the general public and were applauded for their efforts by the nation every Thursday at pm for the first  weeks of the crisis.While the nation has faced restrictions on their movement and social lives, here four doctors from the British Medical Associationdescribe their experiences during the last  days for the PA news agency.ndash Stephanie Rees, a junior doctor at Glan Clwyd Hospital in north Wales, said seeing a patient die without their loved ones at their bedside was a ldquohard moment vw,vw,px, px"Dr Stephanie Rees said PPE has changed the way she communicates with patients ldquoIrsquom what you would call a lsquohuggerrsquo. Passed an exam  Hug for you. Successfully placed a cannula  Hug for you, said the BMA Wales junior doctor committee member.ldquoEarly on, when social distancing was just being introduced, a friend of mine passed their degree and officially became a registered nurse, so what was my first reaction  A faux pas ndash I hugged her, and she recoiled away from me ndash clearly not the reaction I was going for.ldquoMasks and PPE isolate us from not only our patients, but also our colleagues.On families being able to visit patients, she added: ldquoA quick video call is no replacement for holding their hand.ldquoI canrsquot imagine what it would be like to have a loved one in intensive care, not be able to visit, and only get one or two phone calls a day updating me, she said.ldquoThe hardest part is when these conversations are not good news. When we think a patient has deteriorated to the point where there is nothing more we can do, we invite one to two family members into the unit to visit them and say goodbye, but what do we dotheir relative is shielding or vulnerable  We canrsquot in good conscience recommend coming into the Covid section of intensive care, no matter the amount of PPE we provide them.Dr Rees added: ldquoOne of my hardest moments was when a patient passed away without their family with them. The last time they saw them was when they were admitted to hospital. Two nurses sat with the patient the whole time, holding their hand and playing the music they enjoyed.ldquoThis time has brought with it some of my hardest moments as a doctor, but it has also brought some of the most heartwarming.ldquoWhen one of our patients had their birthday, and we managed to get their close family and friends together to do a video chat of them opening their cards that had been delivered to their unit. It was such a small thing for us to do, but it meant so much to the patient and their family.ndash Dr David Wrigley, Lancashire GP and deputy chairman of the BMA Council said he hopes a silver lining of the crisis will be a reduction in red tape for doctors. vw,vw,px, px"Dr Wrigely said he hopes the pandemic will lead to less bureaucracy and paperwork for doctors so they can spend more time with patients ldquoThe way I deliver care has shted drastically over the past three months from the usual face to face surgeries, to telephone and video consultations in order to make care safer for NHS staff and patients, he said.ldquoOne small silver lining of these past  days has been the reduction in box ticking, which has allowed us to focus more of our time on patient care.ldquoI hope that, in the future, the NHS will thoroughly investigate how processes can be simplied, so that doctors can spend more time with patients, as opposed to this bureaucracy and paperwork.ldquoWorking closer with colleagues has fostered a greater sense of camaraderie as wersquove had to deal with ious issues such as PPEshortages and handling a very serious pandemic right on our doorstep.ldquoFor many, this has also been a challenge as a large number of doctors have not yet had any time off and their mental health has therefore suffered as a result.ndash Dr Rebecca Acres, chairwoman of the BMA East Midlands regional council, said that seeing patients leave intensive care in full health ldquomakes all the hardship worthwhile. vw, px"Dr Rebecca Acres described seeing  patients leave intensive care over the last  days ldquoThe past  days have been a steep learning curve for me as I was redeployed at the very beginning from theatre anaesthetics to intensive care.ldquoWhile wersquove probably seen fewer patients over this period, they have been much more unwell than in pre-Covid times. The mortality rate has been four times as high, while patients who are critically unwell remain so for a much longer time ndash in some cases six weeks or more before recovering fully.ldquoItrsquos been a trying period for staff as well as patients. We have had to spend all of our working time in full protective equipment, meaning that communication amongst teams becomes very dficult and comforting colleagues after a hard day is also a challenge.ldquoOver the past  days, wersquove seen just over  patients leave intensive care having made a full recovery. Watching them come back to full health and leave makes all of the hardship worthwhile.ldquoWe keep referring to lsquoafterrsquo in my unit. That time when we can hug our families, go on holiday, hang around in houses with friends, touch patients without full protective gear, talk to relatives without masks on and so on. It seems a while away yet, but Irsquom so looking forward to it.ndash Dr George Gardiner, a member of the BMA Northern Ireland consultants committee and clinical director for the intensive care unit in Belfastrsquos City and Mater Hospitals, who also became clinical director of the Nightingale hospital in Belfast, said: ldquoAs it turned out, the outcomes were much better than we had feared. vw,vw,px, px"Watching patients leave intensive care after prolonged stays was a lsquohigh pointrsquo for Dr George Gardiner On his experience in Nightingale he said: ldquoWe expected and planned for many more patients than we received, though briefly the admission rate seemed to be rising faster than we could mobilise staff and open beds.ldquoMy colleagues succeeded in preparing clinical areas for use as intensive care and preparing staff from other areas to work within it.ldquoTheir efforts in the few weeks before the patients started to arrive were truly remarkable ndash approximately , staff from all disciplines had an induction to critical care in some form, and  beds were ready to take patients with more in reserve.ldquoI think we all expected the mortality to be high and the work to be exhausting. As it turned out, the outcomes were much better than we had feared but the levels of delirium and burden of multiple organ failure was much higher.ldquoThe high points have got to be watching patients finally leave ICU after prolonged stays, working with colleagues who were entirely out of their comfort zone yet enthusiastic and focused, and finally getting out of PPE..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Four doctors reflect on th day of lockdown article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Richmount News.“They are also meant to bring a bit of fun as le in isolation can be rather gloomy and depressing.”Joe said: “It would appear that a lot of agencies seem to think that everyone is on the internet and they avail of social media but this is not the case particularly in the case of the over s. “Of course, there are a lot of older people who use the internet, but many don’t. We wanted to reach out to these people and keep in contact with them. So, we decided to print about  copies of the magazines and DVDs and personally deliver them to older people who we believe are not on the internet. “This also gives our volunteers the opportunity to say hello to these people and establishthey need anything. This is totally non-intrusive and has been welcomed by our older Richmount Rural Community Association Working together for all in our community.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: Three more recycling centres to openControversial DUP motion on name for leisure centre defeatedNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead confirmed its camping facilitieswill reopen at three sites in the borough.By The NewsroomFriday, th June , : pm""Photo by Aaron McCracken HarrisonsThe matter was raised at a Council’s monthly meeting by UUP Alderman Jim Speers who asked when caravan sites across the borough would be reopening.“Gosford generates businesses for Markethill and we want to see that opening up as well as a site in Clare Glen,” said the Alderman.“A lot of people will want to be out and about andit can be done safely at these sites, it should be.”In response to these comments, Council’s strategic director,Mark Parkinson, confirmed caravan sites at both Gosford Forest Park and Clare Glen would open from Friday, June .“Gosford will open on June  and so will Clare Glen,” said Mr Parkinson.“The site at Kinnego will reopen on Friday, July , and at all these sites the caravan, camping, toilet and shower facilities will be available.”SDLP group leader, Councillor Thomas O’Hanlon askedthose who had made bookings before the outbreak of the COVID- pandemic and subsequently had their bookings cancelled, were being contacted to ensure they could still avail of the service.“Some people had booked their slots at these sites early in January and paid for them,” said Cllr O’Hanlon. “They were quickly refunded during the outbreak and that was good and the right thing to do but have we made contact with those people now “They had been on the ball and made their bookings early, it wouldbe a shamethey were now to miss out, when the sites have reopened, through no real fault of their own.”His question went unanswered on the night and when the Local Democracy Reporting Service asked Council for an answer, a spokesperson said it is working to accommodateall bookings.“As Council begins to reopen its caravanning and camping facilities at Clare Glen, Gosford Forest Park and Kinnego Marina, we are working with the public to accommodateall bookings where possible based on reduced capacity and in
